Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Participation of U.S. Scientists in the International Conference on Global Positioning System (GPS) Radio Occultation; Tao-Yuan, Taiwan; May 14-16, 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the travel of US scientists to attend the Second International Conference on GPS Radio Occultation (ICGPSRO) in Tao-Yuan, Taiwan. NSF has a longstanding partnership, through the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research, with the Taiwanese National Space Organization (NSPO), in the development of space-based GPS radio occultation (RO) as a technology for observing the atmosphere. This partnership produced the Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, the Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC), a six-satellite constellation of polar orbiting satellites with GPS receivers (launched in 2006). The COSMIC mission has beeh highly sucessful, and a follow-on mission, COSMIC-2, is under development. COSMIC-2 will consist of two six-satellite constellations, one in polar orbits and one in low-inclination tropical orbits, and the new satellites contain substantial enhancements over the previous generation.

The purpose of this award is to encourage the adoption of COSMIC-2 data by the US research community. The COSMIC-2 tropical constellation, with a planned launch date in Fiscal Year 2016, will provide unprecedented vertical profiles of temperature and moisture in the tropics, as well as coverage of conditions in the tropical ionosphere. This award will allow up to 10 US researchers to attend the meeting and determine the optimal research uses of COSMIC-2 data, and will work with their Taiwanese counterparts to identify areas of common interest and potential US-Taiwanese collaboration.

This award is co-funded by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the International Conference on GPS Radio Occultation (ICGPSRO) held May 14-16, 2013 at the Aspire Center, Tao-Yuan, Taiwan, was to engage and inform the community on opportunities to be made available from the COSMIC-2 mission. These opportunities include familiarizing U.S. scientists with RO techniques, as well as increasing awareness of research applications available to their specific disciplines. For example, the approximately 10,000 RO soundings to be provided by COSMIC-2 will create tremendous opportunities for research on weather and climate processes that have been limited by lack of data, particularly over the tropical ocean. These processes include the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), the El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO), the Quasi-Biannual Oscillations (QBO), tropical cyclogenesis, and monsoon dynamics. In addition, the COSMIC-2 data will provide electronic density profiles at unprecedented density in time and space, making it possible for significant advancement in space weather nowcasting and forecasting. Finally, the COSMIC-2 mission will provide much needed data to support global operational weather prediction and climate monitoring.

Another important goal for the ICGPSRO was to encourage the participation of scientists from various disciplines who have not previously been involved with the development and applications of the GPS RO measurement technique. Training scientists from outside the RO community was and is very important to ensure that the RO data are used effectively in different science disciplines. Fostering collaboration between the U.S. and Taiwan science communities was also a major goal for the workshop. 

A total of ten U.S. scientists from a broad spectrum of scientific disciplines directly relevant to the COSMIC-2 mission were invited to participate in the ICGPSRO Conference held at Taoyuan, Taiwan, in May 2013. These scientific presentations were extremely valuable in educating the U.S. scientists that were new to GPS radio occultation measurement techniques and applications.

Additionally, the scientific presentations given by the U.S. delegation provided an excellent review of current issues in various scientific disciplines that could benefit from the exploitation of the GPS radio occultation data to be made available from the COSMIC-2 mission.

With more than 100 scientists and students attending from 20 countries, the ICGPSRO meeting was a great success and furthered the education of the scientific community of the opportunities to be made available from the COSMIC-2 mission. The participation of the U.S. delegation contributed significantly to the success of the meeting. The engagement of early career scientists was especially important in ensuring future progress in GPSRO research.

This award also supported five U.S. students to attend the Eighth FORMOSAT-3/COSMIC Data Users’ Workshop, held in Boulder, CO, from September 30 to October 2, 2014. Students represent the future of the GPS RO community, and supporting their participation in this workshop was intended to ensure the continued growth of the GPS RO community. In addition, it promoted collaboration among junior and senior scientists, exchange of innovative applications of data in future research, and fostered enthusiasm for continued research on and publication of  weather prediction and climate monitoring utilizing GPSRO techniques.
